intro: Phoradendron pachyphyllum, commonly known as the thick-leaved mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Viscaceae family. It is native to the southeastern United States, particularly Florida and the Caribbean, where it attaches to various host trees such as oaks and hawthorns. The plant has thick, fleshy leaves that store water, allowing it to survive in dry conditions. It produces small, white or yellowish flowers followed by fleshy, sticky berries that are dispersed by birds. Its unique botanical features make it an important part of the ecological interactions in its native habitat.
